1616 (death) | era = | employer = | known_for = [[Saadi dynasty|Moroccan]]-[[Dutch Republic|Dutch]] trade agreement (1608) | notable_works = first Portuguese [[minyan]] Amsterdam {{cite book | first = Mark | last = Kurlansky | title = A Chosen Few: The Resurrection of European Jewry | publisher = Random House | place = New York | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=mOLGqf6HUiAC | page = 82 | date = 2008 | accessdate = 31 August 2016}} | home_town = | criminal_charge = Piracy | criminal_penalty = Case dismissed | spouse = Reina (Hebrew ''Malca'') | partner = | children = Isaac (and Jacob/Carlos) | parents = Isaac Pallache, rabbi | relatives = [[Joseph Pallache]] (brother) and nephews [[Isaac Pallache|Isaac]], Joshua, [[David Pallache|David]], [[Moses Pallache|Moses]], Abraham | family = [[Pallache family]] | awards = | website = }} '''Samuel Pallache''' ([[Hebrew language|Hebrew]]: 'שמואל פאלאץ, ''Shmuel Palach'') (c. 1550 – February 4, 1616), was a [[Jew]]ish-[[Morocco|Moroccan]]-born merchant, diplomat and pirate of the [[Pallache family]], who, as envoy, concluded a treaty with the [[Dutch Republic]] in 1608. He is likely an ancestor of [[Haim Palachi]] of 19th-Century [[Izmir]]. ==Background== Pallache was born in [[Fez, Morocco]]. His father, Isaac Pallache, was a rabbi there, first mentioned in ''[[takkanot]]'' (Jewish community statutes) in 1588. His brother was [[Joseph Pallache]]. His uncle was Fez's grand rabbi, [[Judah Uziel]]; his son [[Isaac Uziel]] was a rabbi of the Neve Shalom community in Amsterdam. His family originated from [[Al-Andalus|Islamic Spain]], where his father had served as [[rabbi]] in [[Córdoba, Spain|Córdoba]]. According to Professor Mercedes García-Arenal, "The Pallaches were a Sephardi family perhaps descended from the ''Bene Palyāj'' mentioned by the twelfth-century chronicler [[Abraham ibn Daud|Abraham Ibn Da’ud]] as 'the greatest of the families of Cordoba'." {{Citation | first = Mercedes | last = García-Arenal | contribution = Pallache Family (Moroccan Branch) | editor-last = Stillman | editor-first = Norman A. | title = Encyclopedia of Jews in the Islamic World | volume = 4 | pages = | publisher = Brill | place = | year = 2010 | contribution-url = http://referenceworks.brillonline.com/entries/encyclopedia-of-jews-in-the-islamic-world/pallache-family-moroccan-branch-COM_0017270}} Sometime in the first half of the 16th Century, following the Christian conquest of Islamic Spain (the ''[[Reconquista]]''), the family fled to Morocco, where Jews, like Christians, were tolerated as long as they accepted [[Islam]] as the official religion. How they arrived is unclear. One Italian historian states, "''Verso i Paesi Bassi emigra anche la famiglia Pallache, forse dal Portogallo o dalla Spagna, oppure, secundo un'altra ipotesti, dalla nativa Spagna emigra a Fez, dove un Isaac Pallache è rabbino nel 1588''" (translation: "The Pallache family also emigrated to the Netherlands, perhaps from Portugal or Spain, or, according to another hypothesis, they emigrated [directly] from their native Spain to Fez, where one Isaac Pallache was rabbi in 1588.") {{cite book | first = Giovanna | last = Fiume | title = Schiavitù mediterranee. Corsari, rinnegati e santi di età moderna | publisher = Bruno Mondadori | place = Milan | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=UmdrZEgiDvwC | year = 2012 | accessdate = 4 September 2016}} (The surname is spelled "Palache" on his death certificate. {{cite web | title = Palache, Samuel (archive card number 19260) | publisher = Dutch Jewry | url = http://www.dutchjewry.org/phpr/amsterdam/port_isr_gem_burials/amsterdam_port_isr_gem_burials_view.php?editid1=19256 | date = | accessdate = 30 August 2016}} He signed his name also as "Palacio" and "Palatio"; other Dutch records show "Palatio," "Palachio," and "Palazzo." As the family spread out of the Iberian peninsula, so did the spellings, which include: de Palatio, al-Palas, Pallas, Palaggi, Balyash, {{cite web | title = The Palache Family | publisher = Jewish Virtual Library | url = http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/judaica/ejud_0002_0015_0_15331.html | accessdate = 1 September 2016 | date = }} as well as Palacci, {{Citation | first = D Gershon | last = Lewental | contribution = Pallache Family (Turkish Branch) | editor-last = Stillman | editor-first = Norman A. | title = Encyclopedia of Jews in the Islamic World | volume = 4 | pages = | publisher = Brill | place = | year = 2010 | contribution-url = http://referenceworks.brillonline.com/entries/encyclopedia-of-jews-in-the-islamic-world/pallache-family-turkish-branch-COM_0017280}} Palaty, {{cite book | title = Studia Rosenthaliana | volume = 4–5 | pages = 112 (Palaty), 221 (Palatie) | publisher = Koninklijke Van Gorcum | place = Assen | year = 1970 | accessdate = 4 September 2016 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=RsYMAQAAMAAJ&dq=%22isaac+pallache%22+fez&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=pallache}} Palatie, and Paliache {{cite book | first = Abraham Isaac | last = Laredo | title = Les noms des juifs de Maroc: Essai d'onomastique judéo-marocaine | publisher = Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Científicas - Instituto Arias Montano | date = 1978 | place = Madrid | pages = 966–971}} There are also Tunisian Jews with the surnames "Palatgi" and "Paligi." {{cite web | url = http://www.sephardicgen.com/names.htm | title = Sephardic Surnames from a number of Jewish Sephardic sources | publisher = SephardicGen | date = | accessdate = 8 September 2016}} Palacci is listed as a Spanish Sephardic name: {{cite web | url = http://www.hsje.org/society/hsjefamilynames.htm | title = Family Names | publisher = Historical Society of Jews From Egypt | date = | accessdate = 12 September 2016}} Pallache is listed as a Portuguese Sephardic name. {{cite web | url = http://www.sephardicstudies.org/portgib.html | last = Abecassis | first = José Maria | title = Genealogia hebraica: Portugal e Gibraltar sécs. XVII a XX | place = Lisboa | publisher = Liv. Ferin | date = | accessdate = 12 September 2016}}) ==Career== [[File:Laureys a Castro - A Sea Fight with Barbary Corsairs.jpg|thumb|right|"A Sea Fight with Barbary Corsairs" by [[Laureys a Castro]] ca. 1681]] Pallache arrived in the Netherlands between 1590 and 1597. {{cite book | first = David | last = Henriques Castro | title = Keur van grafstenen op de Portugees-Isräelietische begraafplaats te Ouderkerk aan de Amstel met beschrijving en biografische aantekeningen: met platen | publisher = Stichting tot Instandhouding en Onderhoud van Historische Joodse Begraafplaatsen in Nederland | pages = 36 (first minyan), 91–93 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=mTRJAQAAIAAJ | date = 1999 | accessdate = 1 September 2016}} In 1591, [[Middelburg, Netherlands|Middelburg]] offered him residential permit, but Protestant pastors protested. {{cite web | first = Jan Willem | last = Schulte Nordholtprijs | title = Van Antwerpen naar Amsterdam | publisher = JoodsAmsterdam | url = http://www.joodsamsterdam.nl/van-antwerpen-naar-amsterdam/ | date = January 2014 | accessdate = 1 September 2016}} After a delegation from the [[Dutch Republic]] visited Morocco to discuss a common alliance against [[Spain]] and the [[Barbary pirate]]s, sultan [[Zidan Abu Maali]] in 1608 appointed the merchant Samuel Pallache to be his envoy to the Dutch government in [[The Hague]]. Officially, Pallache served as his "agent", not ambassador. On June 23, 1608, Pallache met [[stadholder]] [[Maurice of Nassau, Prince of Orange|Maurice of Nassau]] and the [[States-General of the Netherlands|States-General]] in The Hague to negotiate an alliance of mutual assistance against Spain. On December 24, 1610, the two nations signed the [[Morocco–Netherlands relations|Treaty of Friendship and Free Commerce]], an agreement recognising free commerce between the Netherlands and Morocco, and allowing the sultan to purchase ships, arms and munitions from the Dutch.[https://books.google.com/books?id=pUJkIYXBKGMC&pg=PA127 ''Poetry, politics and polemics'' by Ed de Moor, Otto Zwartjes, G. J. H. van Gelder p.127] This was one of the first official treaties between a European country and a non-Christian nation, after the 16th-Century treaties of the [[Franco-Ottoman alliance]].{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} The story goes that, one day, Pallache's horse-drawn carriage met the carriage of the Spanish ambassador in The Hague. The two carriages were unable to pass one another and, to cheers from onlookers, the Spanish ambassador's carriage had to make way for Pallache's carriage. Research has shown that Pallache secretly acted as a double agent.{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} He maintained close ties with the Spanish court and passed classified information about Dutch-Moroccan relations on to the Spanish. At the same time, he was passing information about Spain back to the Dutch and Moroccans. When this eventually came to light, he fell out of favor with the sultan.{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} In addition to his diplomatic affairs, Pallache also continued his activities as a merchant, actively trading between the Netherlands and Morocco. He also got permission from Prince Maurice for [[privateer]]ing activities. The goods obtained through these pirating activities were sold along the Moroccan coast. ==Death== {{Quote box |quote ='''[Archive card number] 19620'''

https://books.google.com/books?id=WtQRAQAAIAAJ | date = 2001 | accessdate = 1 September 2016}} ===Family (Mediterranean rabbis)=== [[File:Abraham palagi.jpg|thumb|right|[[Abraham Palacci]].]] Both ''Les noms des juifs du Maroc'' and ''A Man of Three Worlds'' describe several generations of Pallache family members, which forms the basis of the family descent shown below. Samuel's wife was Reina (Hebrew ''Malca'') (English "Queen"). ''Les noms'' cites two sons, Isaac and Jacob, ''One Man'' cites only Isaac. Samuel's brother Joseph had five sons: [[Isaac Pallache|Isaac]], Joshua, [[David Pallache|David]], [[Moses Pallache|Moses]], and Abraham. ''One Man'' cites Moses (and David) as most influential person after Samuel's death and de facto leader of the family, even before his own (elderly) father Joseph. 19th Century descendants included four grand rabbis, three in Izmir, Turkey ([[Haim Palachi]], [[Abraham Palacci]], and [[Rahamim Nissim Palacci]]) and one in the Netherlands ([[Isaac Juda Palache]])–[[Pallache family#Documented spellings of surname|spellings of the surname varied]] considerably over the centuries). (Please see [[Pallache family#Family tree]] sub-section of the [[Pallache family]] entry for a regularly updated list of his family.) ==="Rabbi Pirate"=== Publication of ''A Man of Three Worlds: Samuel Pallache, a Moroccan Jew in Catholic and Protestant Europe'' in English (Baltimore: Johns Hopkins Press: 2003) and originally in Spanish as ''Entre el Islam y Occident: La vida de Samuel Pallache, judío de Fez'' (Madrid: Siglo XXI 1999) has led to some popular emphasis on Pallache as pirate. A main source of this reputation is Edward Kritzler's book ''Jewish Pirates of the Caribbean'' (2008), which calls Samuel Palache the "Pirate Rabbi" who "was still capturing Spanish ships in his late sixties.". The book led to reviews with titles like "Sephardi Sea Hawks" {{cite news | first = Benjamin | last = Ivry | date = 8 October 2008 | title = Sephardi Sea Hawks | publisher = Forward magazine | accessdate = 1 September 2016 | url = http://forward.com/culture/14339/sephardi-sea-hawks-02634/}} and "Yo Ho Ho and a Bottle of Schnapps" {{cite news | first =Danny | last = Paller | title = Yo Ho Ho The '''San Leandro Tech Campus''' is a [[business park]] being constructed in downtown [[San Leandro, California]], near the [[San Leandro (BART station)|San Leandro BART station]]. Construction of Phase 1 of the project began in 2014, and was completed in 2016. The primary tenant of the first phase of construction is [[OSIsoft]], a software company based in San Leandro.<ref>[http://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/johnson/article/Boom-times-come-to-downtown-San-Leandro-6840782.php]</ref> Phase 2 of the project is expected to be completed in 2019 with [[Ghirardelli Chocolate Company]] as the lead tenant.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bisnow.com/san-francisco/news/office/ghirardelli-chocolate-signs-lease-at-san-leandro-tech-campus-90882|title=Ghirardelli Chocolate Signs Lease At San Leandro Tech Campus|last=|first=|date=July 23, 2018|website=Bisnow|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 10, 2018}}</ref>
The site is the permanent location for the sculpture, ''[[Truth is Beauty]]'', by [[Marco Cochrane]]. The sculpture generated some controversy, as it is a large 55' nude outdoor sculpture, albeit on private property.<ref>[https://www.sanleandro.org/depts/cd/projects/downtown_technology_campus.asp]</ref><ref>[http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/San-Leandro-Truth-is-Beauty-sculpture-nude-9145455.php]</ref><ref>[http://abc7news.com/technology/naked-sculpture-in-san-leandro-stirs-mixed-emotions/868145/]</ref><ref>[http://kron4.com/2016/10/01/truth-is-beauty-sculpture-revealed-in-san-leandro/]</ref>

The '''Sustainable Forestry Initiative''' (SFI) is a North American 'forest certification standard' and program of SFI Inc., a [[non-profit]] organization. The Sustainable Forestry Initiative is the world’s largest single forest certification standard by area.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sfiprogram.org/files/pdf/news-releases/nr-standard-2010-01-12.pdf |title=SFI Inc. Launches New Standard, Leads Forest Certification Forward |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018233553/http://www.sfiprogram.org/files/pdf/news-releases/nr-standard-2010-01-12.pdf |archivedate=2012-10-18 |df= }}</ref>The SFI is headquartered in Ottawa, Ontario Canada and Washington D.C. USA.
In 2005, the [[Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification]] (PEFC), which itself is the world's largest forest certifications system, recognized the SFI standard.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pefc.org/about-pefc/membership/national-members/8-United%20States |title=National Members |publisher=Pefc.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-19}}</ref>
==SFI Program== The SFI Forest Management Standard<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sfiprogram.org/sustainable_forestry_initiative_standard.php |title=SFI Standard - Sustainable Forestry Initiative |publisher=Sfiprogram.org |date=2008-09-09 |accessdate=2013-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130216004800/http://www.sfiprogram.org/sustainable_forestry_initiative_standard.php |archivedate=2013-02-16 |df= }}</ref> covers key values such as protection of biodiversity, species at risk and wildlife habitat; sustainable harvest levels; protection of water quality; and prompt regeneration. A new set of SFI 2015-2019 Standards and Rules, developed through an open review process, took effect on Jan. 1, 2015.<ref name="C5">{{cite web |url=http://www.sfiprogram.org/files/pdf/news-releases/nr-standard-2010-01-12.pdf |title=Sfi Inc. Launches New Standard |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018233553/http://www.sfiprogram.org/files/pdf/news-releases/nr-standard-2010-01-12.pdf |archivedate=2012-10-18 |df= }}</ref> All SFI certifications require independent, third-party audits<ref name="C6">{{cite web |url=http://www.sfiprogram.org/sfi-standard/independent-certification-bodies.php |title=Independent Certification Bodies |publisher=Sfiprogram.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120915082722/http://www.sfiprogram.org/sfi-standard/independent-certification-bodies.php |archivedate=2012-09-15 |df= }}</ref> and are performed by internationally accredited certification bodies.<ref name="C7">{{cite web |url=http://www.sfiprogram.org/sfi-standard/sfi-accreditation.php |title=SFI Accreditation |publisher=Sfiprogram.org |date=2008-09-09 |accessdate=2013-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120915082747/http://www.sfiprogram.org/sfi-standard/sfi-accreditation.php |archivedate=2012-09-15 |df= }}</ref>
The SFI Standards are revised and updated every five years to incorporate the latest scientific information and to respond to emerging issues. As part of this process, comments were received during two 60-day public comment periods in 2013 and 2014, and input was received from 12 public workshops across the United States and Canada. About 10,000 stakeholders were invited to submit comments. Participants included public and private landowners, forest sector representatives, Indigenous communities, conservation groups, industry, academia and government officials.
Independent oversight was provided at each stage of the revision process by the SFI External Review Panel, a group of independent experts representing conservation, professional, academic and public organizations, operating at arm’s length from SFI. The SFI External Review Panel reviewed every public comment submitted to ensure that all comments were considered, and to guarantee the Standard revision process was transparent, objective and credible. The responses to comments are posted on the SFI website.
The SFI Program only certifies lands in the United States and Canada, and program participants must comply with all applicable laws. For sources outside of North America without effective laws, participants must avoid illegal or other controversial sources.<ref name="C20">{{cite web |url=http://www.sfiprogram.org/files/pdf/Section7_sfi_requirements_2010-2014.pdf |title=SFI Requirements 2010-2014 Section 7 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120826175220/http://www.sfiprogram.org/files/pdf/Section7_sfi_requirements_2010-2014.pdf |archivedate=2012-08-26 |df= }}</ref> The SFI Program supports activities by international experts to find ways to address the problem of illegal logging<ref name="C21">{{cite web |url=http://www.sfiprogram.org/forest-conservation/prevent-illegal-logging.php |title=Prevent Illegal Logging |publisher=Sfiprogram.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121014001529/http://www.sfiprogram.org/forest-conservation/prevent-illegal-logging.php |archivedate=2012-10-14 |df= }}</ref> and is a member of the international, multi-stakeholder Forest Legality Alliance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wri.org/fla/ |title=Forest Legality Alliance |publisher=Wri.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-19}}</ref>
The SFI 2015-2019 Fiber Sourcing Standard promotes responsible forestry practices based on 14 Principles, 13 Objectives, 21 Performance Measures and 55 Indicators that address the 90 percent of the world’s forests that are not certified. The SFI 2015-2019 Fiber Sourcing Standard distinguishes SFI from all other forest certification programs in that it sets mandatory practice requirements for the responsible procurement of all fiber, even if it is sourced from non-certified land. These fiber sourcing requirements include measures to broaden the practice of biodiversity, use best management practices to protect water quality, and utilize the services of forest management and harvesting professionals. Because it governs how SFI Program Participants procure fiber from non-certified land, supporters argue that the Standard encourages the spread of responsible forestry practices.
SFI has certified more than 285 million acres (115 million hectares)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfiprogram.org/about-us/basics-of-sfi/|title=Basics of SFI - SFI|author=|date=|website=www.sfiprogram.org|accessdate=16 April 2018}}</ref> to its standard in the [[United States]] and [[Canada]]. At the end of October 2010, SFI had 959 [[chain of custody]] certifications at 2,339 locations. According to the [[United Nations]], SFI was the fastest growing organization for chain of custody certifications in 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://timber.unece.org/fileadmin/DAM/publications/Final_FPAMR2009.pdf |title=2008-2009 Forest Products- Annual Market Review |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100717023154/http://timber.unece.org/fileadmin/DAM/publications/Final_FPAMR2009.pdf |archivedate=2010-07-17 |df= }}</ref>
The Board of Directors that governs the SFI program has three chambers that recognize economic, environmental and social sectors equally.<ref name="C8">{{cite web |url=http://www.sfiprogram.org/sustainable-forestry-initiative/sfi-governance.php |title=SFI Governance |publisher=Sfiprogram.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121014010228/http://www.sfiprogram.org/sustainable-forestry-initiative/sfi-governance.php |archivedate=2012-10-14 |df= }}</ref> Directors include representatives of environmental, conservation, professional and academic groups, independent professional loggers, family forest owners, public officials, labor and the forest products industry.<ref name="C9">{{cite web |url=http://www.sfiprogram.org/board.php#top |title=SFI Board of Directors |publisher=Sfiprogram.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121104014327/http://www.sfiprogram.org/board.php#top |archivedate=2012-11-04 |df= }}</ref>
==Reviews and comparisons ==
===Third-party reviews ===
The [[United Nations Economic Commission for Europe]]/[[Food and Agriculture Organization]], in its ''2009-2010 Forest products Annual Review'', says: "Over the years, many of the issues that previously divided the (certification) systems have become much less distinct. The largest certification systems now generally have the same structural programmatic requirements."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://timber.unece.org/fileadmin/DAM/publications/sp-25.pdf |title=2009-2010 Forest Products- Annual Market Review |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820151542/http://timber.unece.org/fileadmin/DAM/publications/sp-25.pdf |archivedate=2010-08-20 |df= }}</ref>
Dovetail Partners Inc., in its ''2010 Forest Certification: A Status Report'', states: "the previous differences between forest certification programs are much less distinct ... each program generally has the same structural programmatic requirements, although the required content and level of detail provided by each may vary considerably."<ref name=Dove>{{cite web |url=http://www.dovetailinc.org/files/DovetailCertReport0310b.pdf |title=2010 Forest Certification: A Status Report |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-04-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130531220823/http://www.dovetailinc.org/files/DovetailCertReport0310b.pdf |archivedate=2013-05-31 |df= }}</ref>
SFI is generally considered less stringent than that of the [[Forest Stewardship Council]] (FSC).<ref name="NYT">https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/12/science/earth/12timber.html Mireya Navarro, “Environmental Groups Spar Over Certifications of Wood and Paper Products”</ref><ref name="AW">{{cite journal|url=http://www.architectureweek.com/2009/0812/environment_1-1.html |article=FSC Versus SFI|author=Christine MacDonald|date=August 12, 2009|publisher=Architecture Week}}</ref> For example, SFI allows more tree farming and does not require conservation plans or consultation with local and indigenous stakeholders (except for public lands).<ref name="AW"/>
SFI is less highly rated than FSC for example by Consumer Reports “Greener Choices”,<ref>http://www.greenerchoices.org/eco-labels/labelCategory.cfm?labelCategoryName=Sustainable%20Wood “Sustainable Wood”</ref> and Green America.<ref>http://www.greenamerica.org/programs/woodwise/publishers/simplesteps/FSCvsSFI.cfm "FSC: The Premier Forest Certification Program" by Jennifer Gerholdt, Magazine PAPER Project Coordinator</ref> Others rate SFI/PEFC and FSC equally: TerraChoice (part of [[Underwriters Laboratories]] Global Network) in its 2010 Sins of Greenwashing report, like its 2009 one, counts the SFI/PEFC and FSC in its second-tier list of "legitimate" environmental standards and certifications.;<ref name="C17">{{cite web|url=http://sinsofgreenwashing.org/findings/greenwashing-report-2010/ |title=Sins of Greenwashing |publisher=Sins of Greenwashing |date=2012-09-13 |accessdate=2013-02-19}}</ref> as does Environment Canada's EcoLogo.<ref name="C14">{{cite web |url=http://www.ec.gc.ca/education/default.asp?lang=en&n=743D106D-1 |title=Environment Canada's EcoLogo |publisher=Ec.gc.ca |date=2012-02-20 |accessdate=2013-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611114921/http://www.ec.gc.ca/education/default.asp?lang=en&n=743D106D-1 |archivedate=2011-06-11 |df= }}</ref>
A National Association of State Foresters forest certification policy statement<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stateforesters.org/node/1032 |title=NASF Resolution No. 2008-7: Forest Certification Policy Statement |publisher=Stateforesters.org |date=2008-10-01 |accessdate=2013-02-19}}</ref> passed by resolution in 2008 states: "While in different manners, the ATFS (American Tree Farm System), FSC (Forest Stewardship Council), and SFI systems include the fundamental elements of credibility and make positive contributions to forest sustainability. . . . No certification program can credibly claim to be ‘best’, and no certification program that promotes itself as the only certification option can maintain credibility."
=== Green Building Council === On April 5, 2016, the [[U.S. Green Building Council]] issued a [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design]] (LEED) pilot alternative compliance path (ACP) designed to screen out illegal forest products from LEED buildings. While the ACP is being tested as a credit, it will ultimately become a prerequisite that applies to all LEED projects. As a pilot, the ACP does not become a permanent part of the LEED standard without an affirmative vote of the USGBC membership. The ACP pilot recognizes all certified sources - FSC, PEFC, SFI and ATFS and programs.<ref>{{cite web|title=USGBC Announces New LEED Pilot ACP Designed to Help Eliminate Irresponsibly Sourced Materials—Like Illegal Wood—From the Building Material Supply Chain|url=http://www.usgbc.org/articles/usgbc-announces-new-leed-pilot-acp-designed-help-eliminate-irresponsibly-sourced-materials%E2%80%94|website=U.S. Green Building Council}}</ref> The ACP will apply to all LEED v4 rating systems including Homes v4<ref>{{cite web|title=LEED Reference Guide for Homes Design and Construction|url=http://www.usgbc.org/resources/leed-reference-guide-homes-design-and-construction|website=U.S. Green Building Council}}</ref> and to all LEED 2009<ref>{{cite web|title=LEED 2009 Rating System Selection Guidance.” U.S. Green Building Council|url=http://www.usgbc.org/resources/leed-2009-rating-system-selection-guidance|website=U.S. Green Building Council}}</ref> rating systems.
The ACP categorizes the various forest certification standards based on the ASTM D7612-10 (2015) standard, which is titled “Categorizing Wood and Wood-Based Products According to Their Fiber Sources.”<ref>{{cite web|title=Standard Practice for Categorizing Wood and Wood-Based Products According to Their Fiber Sources|url=http://www.astm.org/Standards/D7612.htm|website=American Society for Testing and Materials}}</ref> ASTM ([[ASTM_International|American Society for Testing and Materials]]) International is a globally recognized leader in the development and delivery of voluntary consensus standards.
Other [[green building]] tools, including two [[American National Standards Institute]] (ANSI)-approved rating systems in the United States – ANSI-ICC 700-2008: National Green Building Standard<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nahbgreen.org/Guidelines/ansistandard.aspx |title=National Green Building Standard |publisher=Nahbgreen.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-19}}</ref> and ANSI/GBI 01-2010: Green Building Assessment Protocol for Commercial Buildings (formerly Green Globes U.S.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thegbi.org/green-globes/ansi-gbi-standard.asp |title=ANSI / GBI Standard |publisher=Thegbi.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-19}}</ref>) – [[Green Building Initiative|Green Globes]] and [[Built Green Canada]] recognize wood products certified by credible third-party certification programs like SFI.
=== Conservation organizations === The SFI Program is supported by conservation groups such as [[Conservation International]], [[American Bird Conservancy]], [[Ducks Unlimited]], and the [[Conservation Fund]] (which serves on its Board).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sfiprogram.org/board.php |title=Board Members |publisher=Sfiprogram.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121104014327/http://www.sfiprogram.org/board.php |archivedate=2012-11-04 |df= }}</ref>
Unlike SFI, the FSC included environmental groups such as [[Greenpeace]] among its founders.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fsc.org/history.html|title=History of FSC|publisher=Fsc.org|date=|accessdate=2013-02-19|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120422113655/http://www.fsc.org/history.html|archivedate=2012-04-22|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenpeace.org/usa/en/campaigns/forests/solutions-to-deforestation/ |title=Solutions to Deforestation |publisher=Greenpeace.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-19}}</ref> The [[National Wildlife Federation]] and [[World Wide Fund for Nature]] (WWF) currently serve on the FSC Board.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fsc.org/bod.html |title=Board of Directors |publisher=Fsc.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120503212719/http://www.fsc.org/bod.html |archivedate=2012-05-03 |df= }}</ref> The [[Sierra Club]] endorses only FSC.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sierraclub.org/committees/forestcertification/ |title=Forest Certification Committee |publisher=Sierraclub.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130301171528/http://www.sierraclub.org/committees/forestcertification/ |archivedate=2013-03-01 |df= }}</ref>
==Critiques of SFI==
===Marketing practices=== On September 9, 2009 the Washington State Forest Law Center, on behalf of the environmental protection group ForestEthics, filed complaints against SFI Inc. with the Federal Trade Commission<ref name="C23">{{cite web|url=http://wflc.org/cases/credibleforestcert/SFIcomplaints |title=Complaints filed against SFI |publisher=Wflc.org |date=2009-09-09 |accessdate=2013-02-19}}</ref> and the Internal Revenue Service.<ref name="C23"/>
The FTC complaint accuses SFI Inc. of misleading consumers with deceptive marketing practices. The complaint cites various aspects of SFI’s marketing, including its claim that it is an “independent” not-for-profit organization, its dependence on the timber industry for funding, and the vagueness of SFI’s environmental standards, which allow SFI-certified landowners to be certified merely because the landowner is complying with state environmental regulations. The complaint cites SFI’s certification as an example of [[greenwash]].
Both the FTC and IRS investigated the complaints made against SFI and found them without merit. No action was taken by either investigative body.{{Citation needed|reason=A link to the IRS and FTC investigation needed to verify this claim|date=September 2015}}
===Conflict of interest=== The complaint filed with the IRS requests an examination of SFI Inc.’s non-profit status, based on the fact that SFI benefits the private interests of its corporate landowners and not the public interest, as well as the fact that SFI draws more than 80% of its funding from the wood and paper industry.<ref name="C24">{{cite web|url=http://gisf.research.yale.edu/assets/pdf/ypfc_perspectives/fsc_sfi_comparison.pdf|title=THE FOREST STEWARDSHIP COUNCIL AND THE SUSTAINABLE FORESTRY INITIATIVE: POINTS OF COMPARISON|author=|date=|website=yale.edu|accessdate=16 April 2018}}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> The complaint asserts that in serving the private interests of wood and paper companies that want a ‘green’ image, SFI is inappropriately granted a nonprofit status reserved for public charities.<ref name="C25">[http://forestethics.org/downloads/SFI_IRS_complaint.pdf Washington State Forest Law Center complaint against SFI filed with IRS] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100706181943/http://forestethics.org/downloads/SFI_IRS_complaint.pdf |date=July 6, 2010 }}</ref>
The IRS investigated the complaint as well as conducted a thorough examination of SFI’s non-profit status and concluded that it was appropriate and that no further action was required.{{Citation needed|reason=A link to the IRS investigation needed to verify this claim|date=September 2015}}
=== Sierra Club complaint ===
The [[Sierra Club]] has lodged a formal complaint with the SFI,<ref name="C26">{{cite web|url=http://wflc.org/cases/credibleforestcert/SFI%20Complaint |title=Sierra Club complaint filed with SFI |publisher=Wflc.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-19}}</ref> alleging that [[Weyerhaeuser]] engaged in risky and irresponsible logging on steep slopes that led to 1,259 landslides in 2007 on SFI-certified Weyerhaeuser lands in Washington state.<ref name="C27">{{cite web|url=http://www.architectureweek.com/2009/1021/news_2-1.html |title=High Tension Over Big Timber |publisher=Architectureweek.com |date=2009-10-21 |accessdate=2013-02-19}}</ref><ref name="C28">{{cite web|url=http://www.dnr.wa.gov/Publications/ger_ofr2008-5_dec2007_landslides.pdf |title=Landslide Reconnaissance Following the Storm Event of December 1–3, 2007, in Western Washington |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-02-19}}</ref> Challenging SFI to back up its claims of 'independence' and 'rigorous audits,' the Sierra Club requested that Weyerhaeuser's SFI certification be revoked.<ref name="C26" />
A peer reviewed landslide study concluded that the Washington State landslides that the Sierra Club attributed to Weyerhaeuser’s logging practices were the result of extreme weather conditions such as heavy rainfall and not the result of steep slope logging by the company.{{Citation needed|reason=A link to the study needed to verify this claim|date=September 2015}} Landslides occur on both logged and unlogged sites, but science shows that logging (and logging roads) dramatically increase the risk of landslides.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oregonwild.org/sites/default/files/pdf-files/Heiken,%20D.%20Landslides%20and%20clearcuts%20-%20science.pdf|title=LANDSLIDES AND CLEARCUTS: What Does The Science Really Say?|last=Heiken|first=Doug|date=|website=www.oregonwild.org|publisher=Oregon Wild|access-date=February 2, 2017}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Sustainable development}} * [[Certified wood]] * [[Sustainable forest management]]
== References == {{Reflist|3}}
==External links== * [http://www.sfiprogram.org/ Sustainable Forestry Initiative, Inc.] * [http://www.pefc.org/ Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090406084642/http://www.proforest.net/cpet/documents Central Point of Expertise on Timber 2008 Forest Certification Assessment] * [https://www.cnbc.com/id/33417397 Conservation Fund President and CEO Larry Selzer, on forest certification]

[[File:Theodore Dietrich Garbade.jpg|thumb|Theodore Dietrich Garbade]] '''Theodore Dietrich Garbade''' (September 12, 1873 – January 26, 1961) was a merchant and [[bank]]er, he was President of the Union of Manufacturers of Cigars of [[Cuba]].
As a young man he moved from the German Village of Cigarmakers “''Zigarrenmacherdorf'' “Hastedt,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.edition-temmen.de/blog/tag/hastedt/|title=Hastedt – DENN MAN TAU|website=www.edition-temmen.de|language=de-DE|access-date=2017-10-02}}</ref> [[Bremen]] to Cuba where he worked as a leaf buyer for [[Hermann Dietrich Upmann]] and his [[Tobacco industry|Tobacco]] Company.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=UJRBAQAAMAAJ&q=Teodore+Garbade+Cigar&dq=Teodore+Garbade+Cigar&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiUhJmW2czWAhWRKVAKHZcID5gQ6AEIKDAA|title=United States Tobacco Journal|date=1915|publisher=BMT Publications|language=en}}</ref> He was President of the Union of Manufacturers of Cigars of [[Cuba]], and joined [[H. Upmann|H.Upmann]] as an associate member and became their partner<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.es/books?id=2MozAQAAMAAJ&q=Theodor+Garbade&dq=Theodor+Garbade&hl=es&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi1tMPv18rWAhWRaVAKHdvNDdQQ6AEIPDAD|title=The London Banks and Kindred Companies and Firms ...|last=(bart.)|first=Sir Thomas Skinner|date=1916|publisher=T. Skinner & Company|language=en}}</ref> at the Bank: [[H. Upmann & Co.]] till 1917 when he moved to [[New York City|New York]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=G5JBAQAAMAAJ&q=teodoro+garbade&dq=teodoro+garbade&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjxzNHptsrWAhUKYlAKHQoMC0YQ6AEIJjAA|title=United States Tobacco Journal|date=1914|publisher=BMT Publications|language=en}}</ref> He was Head of the [[Chamber of commerce|Chamber of Commerce]] in Cuba in 1917.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=JkAwAQAAMAAJ&q=teodoro+garbade&dq=teodoro+garbade&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjxzNHptsrWAhUKYlAKHQoMC0YQ6AEIODAD|title=Memoria que la Junta Directiva presentara a la asamblea general ordinaria|last=Cuba|first=Cámara de Comercio, Industria y Navegación de la Isla de|date=1917|publisher=Cámara|language=es}}</ref>
Theodore Garbade played a significant role in the settlement between Cuba and the [[United States]] after, [[Woodrow Wilson|President Wilson]] succeeded 1913 in passing the [[Revenue Act of 1913|Revenue Act,]] also known as the Tariff Act, or the Underwood Act. The Act established the lowest rates since the [[Walker Tariff]] of 1857. Most schedules were ''ad valorem'' basis, a percentage of the value of the item. This had a profound impact for the Cuban [[Tobacco industry|Tobacco Industry]] concerning their import to the States. As President of the Union of Manufacturers of Cigars of [[Cuba]] Garbade, aided by an appointed committee, laid this out to Cuban ´s President [[Mario García Menocal]] in January 1914, insisting upon an allowance of 50 per cent on their exports of cigars as an equivalent in Cuba’s next reciprocity treaty and urging a prompt solution of this matter so vital to the Cuban cigar industry.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forgottenbooks.com/en/readbook/TheCubaReview_10559666#106|title=The Cuba Review|website=www.forgottenbooks.com|language=en|access-date=2017-10-02}}</ref>
A German [[Citizenship|Citizen]] in the United States in 1916, he was considered [[prisoner of war]], and put under [[house arrest]] in his mansion in [[Mount Kisco, New York|Mount Kisko]], New York. In 1919 he moved to [[San Sebastián|San Sebastian]], [[Spain]] and in 1921 to [[Lucerne]], [[Switzerland]] where he applied for a Swiss passport. Owner of [[plantation]]s and other properties in Cuba, he lost a great part of his fortune by [[Confiscation]] in 1960 after the [[Cuban Revolution]]. He died only one year later. Garbade was married four times. Theodor jr, is son of his first spouse Graziella Aguirre del Monte who died in 1909. His second wife Aida Heydrich (1887 -1920),<ref>New York City Marriage licences,Index 1807-1995, Manhattan 2016</ref> daughter of [[Emilio Heydrich]], gave him two sons: [[Robert D. Garbade]] [[Filmmaking|(Filmmaker]] and first [[Camera operator|cameraman]] of the [[Schweizer Fernsehen|Swiss Television]]) and [[Bernhard Garbade|Bernhard R. Garbade]], director of “[[Zurich Insurance Group|Zurich]]” Insurance Group, [[Philanthropy|Philanthropist]] and [[Sponsor (commercial)|sponsor]] of {{Interlanguage link|Max Maag|de|Max Maag|WD=}} Church Organs. Theodore Garbade is buried with his last wife Hildegard von Ohlen (1903 -1962)<ref>England & Wales Citvil registration marriage index, 1916-2005,page no 1511, von Ohlen,Garbade</ref> at the [[Flims|Flims Waldhaus]] cemetery, Switzerland.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=bDcLAAAAYAAJ&q=teodoro+garbade&dq=teodoro+garbade&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjxzNHptsrWAhUKYlAKHQoMC0YQ6AEIKjAB|title=Historia de familias cubanas|last=Jaruco)|first=Francisco Xavier de Santa Cruz y Mallén (conde de San Juan de|date=1940|publisher=Editorial Hércules|isbn=9780897294089|language=es}}</ref>
== Literature == * Reginald Lloyd, Jose' Pla' Carceles: ''Twentieth Century Impressions of Cuba'',Editor: Lloyds Greater Britain publishing Company, Limited, 1913 * ''The Cuba Review and Bulletin, Editor:Munson Steamship Line, 1913'' * ''United States Tobacco Journa''l,Vol.83, BMT Publications, 1915 * Thomas Skinner: ''The London Banks and Kindred Companies and Firms'', Editor: T. Skinner & Company, 1916 * Martin Torodash: ''Woodrow Wilson and the Tarriff Question: The Importance of the Underwood Act in His Reform Program''.Editor: New York University, Graduate School of Arts and Science, 1966<ref>{{cite book|title=Woodrow Wilson and the Tarriff Question: The Importance of the Underwood Act in His Reform Program|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=yO47ygAACAAJ&dq=underwood+act&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi34KyM7YTXAhXIwxQKHbWbDu4Q6AEIJjAA|publisher=New York University, Graduate School of Arts and Science|date=1966|accessdate=2017-10-22|language=en|first=Martin|last=Torodash}}</ref> * Alfredo Gómez Llorens: ''Instituciones y ciclo económico de la República de Cuba''. Palibrio, 2014 * Noel Maurer: ''The Empire Trap: The Rise and Fall of U.S. Intervention to Protect American'' ,Editor: Princeton University Press,2013, {{ISBN|978-0-691-15582-1}}

'''Value measuring methodology''' (or VMM) is a tool that helps [[financial planner]]s balance both tangible and intangible values when making [[investment decisions]], and monitor benefits.
Formal methods to calculate the [[Return on investment]] (ROI) have been widely understood and used for a long time, but there was no easy and widely known way to provide a formal justification for decisions based on intangible values, which can include the reputation of an organization, the wellbeing of staff, or the impact on society or the environment at large. It was particularly difficult for decision makers to work through the trade-offs between costs and intangible benefits, especially for long-term investments by commercial organizations, and for governments and non-profit organizations who are primarily concerned with intangible values without wasting limited funds. Even within commercial organizations, units traditionally viewed as "cost centres" found it difficult to get acceptance of proposals for projects that would lead to general and long-term efficiency or capability gains, as the benefits were difficult to assign to "profit centres".
The approach of the VMM is to start by developing a framework of values, including costs, risks, tangible returns and intangible returns, then assign scores to each element in the framework. Once the relative scores of the different types of values are assigned and agreed, it becomes possible to examine alternatives and give yes/no decisions in a fairly objective and repeatable manner, and review progress using a range of traditional quantitative program management techniques. As well as allowing comparison of different values within a project, the quantitative approach of the VMM permits review of the total contribution to a particular value across a range of projects.
==History and Adoption== VMM was developed by the General Services Administration's (GSA) Office of Government-wide Policy (OGP) in collaboration with Harvard University. The VMM was first articulated in a report by [[Booz Allen Hamilton]] in 2002 for the US Social Security Administration, as part of an [[E-Services|electronic services]] project.<ref>Dan Remenyi (2006). ''Proceedings of the 13th European Conference on Information Technology Evaluation''. p.182</ref>
It was popularized by a suite of documents released by the [[US Federal Chief Information Officers Council]] in 2003, which give detailed guidance to agencies helping them to seek funding and plan budgets for their proposals, analyze their investments for values across their portfolio of initiatives, and track both tangible and intangible returns over time, with a particular emphasis on information technology investments and the production of ''OMB-300'' exhibits for the [http://www.whitehouse.gov/omb US Office of Management and Budget]. The introductory document<ref>[http://www.cio.gov/documents/TheValueof_IT_Investments.pdf Introductory document]</ref> was given the significant title ''It's Not Just Return on Investment Anymore''.
The suite of documents from the US CIO Council include the following, which are readily adapted for other countries and non-government organizations:<ref>Nagy K. Hanna (2010). ''Transforming Government and Building the Information Society''. p.288</ref> *FAQ (Frequently Asked Questions) *Introduction *How-To-Guide *Highlights (key elements from the how-to guide, and probably the best document for initial study) <!-- (More work is needed here on the adoption of the VMM by non-US governments) (More work is needed here on the adoption of the VMM by non-government organizations.) (More work is needed here on specific projects that have used VMM) -->
==Outline of the steps in the VMM== Each of the four major steps of the VMM process has tasks and outputs. The breakdown below, and the description of major value factors, is based primarily on the suite of VMM documents from the [[US Federal Chief Information Officers Council]] in 2003.
===Develop a decision framework=== *Tasks **Identify and define value structure **Identify and define risk structure **Identify and define cost structure **Begin documentation *Outputs **Prioritized value factors **Defined and prioritized measures within each value factor **Initial risk factor inventory **Risk tolerance boundary **Tailored cost structure **Initial documentation of basis of estimate of cost, value and risk
Forcing the development of the decision framework, with the assignment of scores to intangibles allowing comparison to other intangibles as well as tangibles, eases the resolution of differences of perspectives between senior managers (e.g. Chief Financial Officer, Risk Manager, and the proposer of the initiative), allows changes to the scores to flow through to the rest of the process (especially the analysis of alternatives), and provides clarity of benefits to a board (before, during, and after the initiative), and clarity of priorities to people looking after more detailed aspects of the initiative. The same transparency of values apply if the proposal is developed at an enterprise level, or within a lesser organizational unit.
'''Major value factors''' (from which the value hierarchy is developed) include the following *direct customer value: benefits to customers/clients, e.g. convenient access, product enhancement *social: benefits to society as a whole, e.g. reducing CO<sub>2</sub> emissions *operational: better operations and lowering barriers to future initiatives, e.g. improved infrastructure *strategic: contributions to strategic initiatives and fulfilling the mission of the organization *financial: financial benefits, including increased revenue, decreased costs, and cost avoidance
===Analyze alternatives=== *Tasks **Identify and define alternatives **Estimate value and cost **Conduct risk analysis **Ongoing documentation *Outputs **Viable alternatives for solutions **Cost and value analyses **Risk analyses **Tailored basis of estimate documenting value, cost, and risk, economic factors and assumptions
===Pull the information together=== *Tasks **Aggregate the cost estimate **Calculate the return on investment **Calculate the value score **Calculate the risk score **Compare value, cost, and risk *Outputs **Cost estimate **ROI metrics **Value score **Risk scores (cost and value) **Comparison of cost, value and risk
===Communicate and document=== *Tasks **Communicate value to customers and stakeholders **Prepare budget justification document **Satisfy ad hoc reporting requirement **Use lessons learned to improve processes *Outputs **Documentation, insight and support: ***To develop results-based management controls ***For enterprise budget reporting and analysis ***To communicative initiative value ***For improving decision making and performance measurement through "lessons learned" **Change and ad hoc reporting requirements
==Uses in Capital Investment Planning== A holistic approach to Capital Investment Planning (CIP), using the portfolio approach, requires a significant amount of supporting documentation. The VMM approach can provide planning data and performance assessment criteria for the following:
*Summary of spending *Project description and justification *Performance goals and measures *Alternatives analysis *Risk inventory and assessment *Program management (partial) *Acquisition strategy (partial) *Project and funding plan (partial) *Business case criteria (partial)
In particular, VMM allows quantitative reporting of commitments to particular intangibles across a number of initiatives, even when they differ by their stage in their lifecycles.
== Related theories == *[[Val IT]] – Getting value from IT investments (published by [[ISACA]]), which helps link VMM to IT governance. *[[Risk management]] – as risks play a large part in VMM *[[Enterprise architecture]] – as enterprise architects are central players in planning programs of work *[[Value theory]] – as this provides a core background to understanding what people value *[[Enterprise Asset-Based Value Measurement]] – a structured and rigorous method of viewing and analysing the enterprise as a comprehensive and inter-related set of assets that drive performance and value optimisation - see Enterprise Value matriX (EVX) <www.evxcompany.com> *[[Social earnings ratio]] - the non-financial corollary to the financial metric price earnings ratio
==See also== * [[Value networks]] * [[Value network analysis]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== Further reading == * [http://www.smartcard.gov/information/measuring_finalreport.pdf Building a Methodology for Measuring the Value of E-Services] – the first articulation of VMM *[https://cio.gov/wp-content/uploads/downloads/2012/11/ValueMeasuring_Methodology_HowToGuide_Oct_2002.pdf The VMM How-To Guide] *[http://www.cio.gov/documents/ValueMeasuring_Highlights_Oct_2002.pdf Highlights from the VMM How-To Guide] *[http://www.cio.gov/documents/TheValueof_IT_Investments.pdf The Introduction to VMM] *[http://www.cio.gov/documents/vmm_faq.pdf VMM FAQ] *[http://www.gao.gov/policy/itguide/homepage.htm IT Investment Guidance] from the US General Accounting Office *[http://www.fgdc.gov/policyandplanning/50states/introduction-to-vmm-bah-0ct-2004.pdf Introduction to VMM for fgdc.gov] by Booz Allen Hamilton *[http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d06250.pdf GAO-06-250] "Information Technology: Agencies Need to Improve the Accuracy and Reliability of Investment Information" (Jan 2006) from [http://www.gao.gov US General Accounting Office] *[http://www.ogc.gov.uk/documents/HM_Treasury_-_Measuring_the_expected_benefits_of_e-government.pdf Measuring the expected benefits of e-government] – Appendix 5 "Generic Cost Elements for IT Projects" from [http://www.ogc.gov.uk UK Office of Government Commerce] *[http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&lr=&q=%22Value+Measuring+Methodology%22+site%3Aanao.gov.au+OR+site:agimo.gov.au VMM references] from [http://www.anao.gov.au ANAO] (Australian National Audit Office) and [http://www.agimo.gov.au AGIMO] (Australian Government Information Management Office) *[http://www.evxcompany.com measuring all the assets that drive enterprise performance and value creation]
== External links == *[http://www.cio.gov US Federal Chief Information Officers Council] *[http://www.estrategy.gov/presentations/vmm_workshop US Gov eStrategy VMM Workshop]
